President Bush, on a final pre-election campaign swing to help Republicans, reiterated today that he would sign the recently passed legislation strengthening the Clean Air Act but voiced opposition to a sweeping California ballot proposition, known as "Big Green," that would severely curb use of pesticides and chemicals.

"When it comes to the environment, in order to keep our environment green, we don't have to be Big Green," the President said in a campaign speech for Senator Pete Wilson, the Republican nominee for governor.

The ballot proposition, supported widely by environmental organizations, would phase out cancer-causing pesticides, ban ozone-depleting chemicals and reduce gaseous emissions that contribute to global warming, among other provisions.
The measure is opposed by water, timber, agricultural and manufacturing industries.

After the President spoke today, his Administration's leading environmental official, William K. Reilly, said he did not have a public position on Big Green. He told reporters that it had some laudable provisions, but he also cited its costs and said, "It is not sound scientifically."
From here, Mr. Bush headed to New Mexico to stump for that state's Repubican gubernatorial nominee, Frank Bond, and other candidates.
